New Template Project

Source: vignettes/project.Rmd
project.Rmd

Create a Soil Health Report Project

We assume you are working in RStudio Desktop. This workflow has not been tested in other IDEs such as Visual Studio Code.

There are two ways to create the RStudio project.

Option 1. Open RStudio > File > New Project > "Soil Health Quarto Report"

RStudio Project Wizard with Soil Health Quarto Report selected

Option 2. In the console, run:

soils::create_soils(path = "path/to/project")

The following should print in your console:

Output from running soils::create_soils() in the RStudio console. usethis::create_project() prints the steps to creating the new project directory.

Project Structure

Both options will create and launch a new RStudio project with:

  1. inst folder containing the Quarto template, child documents, example data, images, and style resources. Read the Soil Health Report Article for more information about each of these components and our recommended workflow for modifying them.

  2. R folder with R scripts with the source code for most soils functions for customization.

    • Note: If you decide to change these functions, you will need to update _producerReport.qmd. For example, if you change the make_ft() function in the tables.R file, you should add source(here::here("R/tables.R") to the top {r setup} chunk. Read the Visualization Functions Article for more details.
Project Structure 
├── inst
│   ├── _producerReport.qmd
│   ├── 01_project_summary.qmd
│   ├── 02_soil_health_background.qmd
│   ├── 03_physical_measurements.qmd
│   ├── 04_biological_measurements.qmd
│   ├── 05_chemical_measurements.qmd
│   ├── 06_looking_forward.qmd
│   ├── 07_acknowledgement.qmd
│   ├── extdata
│   │   ├── dataDictionary.csv
│   │   ├── dfPlot.csv
│   │   ├── dfTexture.csv
│   │   ├── exampleData.csv
│   │   ├── headers.RDS
│   │   └── tables.RDS
│   ├── images
│   │   ├── biological.png
│   │   ├── chemical.png
│   │   ├── logo.png
│   │   └── physical.png
│   ├── resources
│   │   ├── styles.css
│   │   └── word-template.docx
└── R
    ├── data_wrangling.R
    ├── helpers.R
    ├── map.R
    ├── plots.R
    ├── render.R
    └── tables.R

Render the Report Template

If you used the RStudio IDE to create the project, the main Quarto template _producerReport.qmd should automatically open in the new project session. If you used soils::create_soils(), you will need to open the inst folder to access this file in the Files pane.

RStudio Files pane showing .qmd files and resources inside the project > inst folder

Once _producerReport.qmd is open, click the Render button at the top of the file to generate either the HTML or MS Word report.

RStudio Quarto render button with a dropdown for HTML and MS Word

This renders the report in the inst directory and the file name will match the input .qmd name. This is the fastest way to render reports and is great for iterating on content and style.

When you’re ready to render reports for all producers in your project, you should use the render_producer_report() function. The year and producer ID are incorporated in the file name (ex. 2023_WUY05_Report.html). You can specify the output directory where you want the reports to be stored. To iterate through each producer ID and year to render all reports at once, use purrr::walk(). See example R code and read the article on Soil Health Reports for more details.
